Description: Head of hand-made terracotta male figure, made from coarse red-brown Egyptian siltware. Visage is narrow, and the main features are roughly indicated : straight nose, browridge, cheekbones, protruding or bearded chin. Ears are not represented. The head wears a high headdress with as slightly protruding axial ridge (crested helmet or "Phrygian" cap?).
Curator's comments: Higgins, Catalogue of Terracottas vol. 1, 408 no. 1553: The head recalls the heads of Cypriote figures (Winter vol. 1, 12 and 15 passim) and of a group of pieces from Memphis depicting foreigners (Mempihs vol. 1, pls. 26ff.)

W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 72 § 68 : the terracotta' soldiers' heads (fig. 7 and 8) are probably of the seventh century also, by the extreme rudeness of them; they both show the crested helmet".
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (1553)
Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 72 § 68, pl. xxiv, 8)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.49, p.56-57, p.177, pl.19)
